progressions.theory: The I-V-vi-IV progression is the most popular in modern pop — its resolution from Am back to F creates an uplifting, familiar loop.
The simplest major turnaround — three chords, all major, no tension. Pure brightness with nowhere to hide.
The I-IV-V-IV in D major keeps energy high — the open A and G chords ring naturally on guitar.
The I-IV-V triad — the foundation of rock and country. Three chords is all you need for a feel-good song.
IV-I-V-vi-IV extends the classic cycle with a minor detour through Am before landing back on F — familiar but with a longer arc.
The I-vi-ii-V is a classic jazz-pop turnaround — the ii-V movement at the end adds forward motion while keeping things cheerful.
I-vi-IV-V-I — the full resolution back to G at the end provides a complete, satisfying cycle that lands with a smile.
I-vi-IV-V in D — the Bm adds a touch of warmth before the G and A lift the progression back up.
I-V-vi-IV with the F#m providing a gentle emotional tug before D resolves back to brightness.
I-V-vi-IV-I — the full cycle in E major. Landing back on E gives a satisfying sense of arrival.
Ascending diatonic sevenths (Imaj7-ii7-iii7-IVmaj7) create a dreamy, sophisticated happiness — common in neo-soul and jazz pop.
Descending diatonic sevenths capped with a dominant V7 — the cascading fall meets a turnaround that bounces you back up.
A three-chord ascending climb through diatonic sevenths — minimal, spacious, and warm. Each chord feels like a step into sunlight.
The I-iii-IVmaj7-V7 movement uses the iii chord for color and the dominant 7th to create a jazzy, buoyant resolution.
Imaj7-iii7-IVmaj7-ii7-V7 — a five-chord jazz cycle. The ii7-V7 at the end creates a sophisticated pull back to the top.
Starting on the minor tonic and moving to major chords creates a sense of reaching for hope but never quite arriving.
Three chords — minor to major to major. The simplicity makes the sadness feel bare and exposed.
All minor chords — the iv-i-v-i cycle stays in darkness, creating a heavy, sorrowful atmosphere.
i-iv-VII-III-VI — a five-chord descent that keeps drifting further from home, like a long walk with no destination.
i-iv-VII-III in E minor — the D and G majors provide fleeting brightness before Em pulls you back down.
The major V chord (E) borrowed from harmonic minor creates a dramatic pull back to Am — sadness with theatrical tension.
i-VI-III-VII in D minor — the Bb adds weight and the F-C movement teases resolution without delivering it.
The major V (B) from harmonic minor adds a classical, almost tragic quality to the resolution back to Em.
Descending bass line (A-G-F-E) creates an Andalusian cadence — one of the oldest and most powerful expressions of sorrow in Western music.
i-VI-III-VII-iv — five chords in flat keys give a darker, heavier color. Ending on Fm deepens the sorrow instead of resolving it.
Seventh chords soften the edges of sadness — the Dm7 to E7 resolution adds jazz-inflected melancholy.
Three lush chords — the Em9 opens wide, Cmaj7 provides momentary warmth, and B7 pulls back with dramatic finality.
A six-chord cycle weaving through the relative major before the Bm7b5-E7 pulls back to minor — a full emotional journey in one loop.
The descending bass (A-G-F-E) with slash chords and sevenths creates a cinematic, slowly falling feeling.
i7-VI7-iv7-V7 in B minor — the major seventh chords add shimmer to the darkness, like moonlight on water.
I-vi-IV-V moves gently between stability and motion — predictable enough to feel safe, varied enough to stay interesting.
A three-chord meditation — I to IV and back. The simplicity itself is the calm.
I-V-IV — three major chords with no minor tension. Feels like an open field.
vi-I-V-IV-iii — five chords that drift gently downward, like leaves settling on still water.
vi-I-V-IV creates a wide, open sound — the spacing between chords gives each one room to breathe.
I-iii-vi-V uses the iii chord (Em) as a gentle stepping stone — adds color without disrupting the calm.
I-iii-IV-V — the Bm provides a brief moment of depth before the familiar IV-V resolution settles things back.
I-iii-IV-ii-V — five chords that meander gently. The Em (ii) before the V is like a long, slow inhale before resolution.
i-VI-III-v stays suspended — ending on Em instead of a strong resolution keeps the mood floating and serene.
IV-vi-V — three chords that avoid the tonic entirely. Floating without an anchor creates a weightless calm.
Adding sevenths to the classic I-vi-IV-V softens every chord — the extended harmony creates a warm, ambient blanket of sound.
Imaj7-iii7-IVmaj7-ii7-V7 — five diatonic sevenths that drift like clouds. No sharp edges anywhere.
Imaj7-vi7-ii7-V7 — a jazz-inflected turnaround that resolves gently. The seventh chords keep everything smooth.
Three seventh chords — IV7-I7-ii7. Minimal movement, maximum warmth. Like sitting in a sunbeam.
Imaj7-vi7-IVmaj7-ii7-V7 — a five-chord lush cycle. The ii7-V7 ending nudges back gently rather than pulling.
I-IV-V — the three-chord engine of rock and roll. No filler, no detours, pure drive.
I-IV-V-I is the simplest rock progression — each chord hits hard and resolves with authority.
I-IV-V-IV-I — a five-chord arc that launches, peaks on D, and crashes back to G. Stadium-rock energy.
I-V-IV-V — the repeated return to A (V) creates a pulsing, restless energy that drives forward.
I-IV-V — the three major chords of C. Strummed hard and fast, this is punk-rock simplicity.
I-bIII-IV-V borrows the flat third (G) from minor — this major/minor ambiguity is the backbone of rock and blues energy.
i-III-VII-VI-V — five chords descending then snapping to the dominant. The E major at the end creates an urgent pull back to the top.
V-IV-I shifted with a borrowed IV (F approached from D) — the unexpected movement creates excitement and momentum.
I-bIII-IV-V — the borrowed flat third (C) adds a bluesy punch. Four ascending chords build relentless forward energy.
i-III-VII — three chords that bounce between minor grit and major punch. Lean and explosive.
A 12-bar blues skeleton condensed to four chords — dominant sevenths add grit and tension that never fully resolves.
Power chord riff ascending in fourths — stripping to root-fifth removes harmony, leaving raw rhythmic aggression.
A six-chord cycle that builds momentum through sheer length — the return to Em after six changes feels like a victory lap.
I-bIII-IV-V-I — five chords with a blues-rock borrowed Bb. The ascending root motion builds to a triumphant return to G.
The walking bass (D-F#-G-A) in the slash chord creates a marching, anthemic build. The A7 snaps it back to the top.
The i-VI-III-VII creates a sense of longing by never fully resolving — each major chord offers hope, but Am always pulls you back.
Three chords — minor home, then two majors that drift away. The simplicity makes the ache more exposed.
i-III-VII-v-i — five chords that wander through relatives before circling back to Dm. The return feels like resignation.
i-v-VI-III — moving between minor chords first deepens the sadness before the major chords offer brief relief.
i-iv-VI — three chords. The Am darkens the mood, and the C never feels bright enough to lift it.
The Andalusian cadence — a descending bass line (A-G-F-E) creates one of music's most recognizable expressions of bittersweet longing.
i-VI-III-V-i — the major V (A) pulls back to Dm with cinematic inevitability. The five-chord arc feels like a complete story.
Descending stepwise (E-D-C-B) — each chord drops a whole step, creating a slow, inevitable descent into deeper emotion.
i-iv-V — three chords. The E major from harmonic minor turns a simple cadence into something dramatic and weighty.
i-VI-III-VII-iv — five chords in flat keys create a darker palette. Ending on Fm deepens the melancholy instead of resolving it.
Seventh chords blur the boundaries between sadness and beauty — the Fmaj7 and Cmaj7 shimmer against the minor tonic.
Five chords weaving through diatonic sevenths before the B7 dominant pulls back — a long, winding path through melancholy.
The Dm9 opens with rich sadness, the Gm7 (iv7) adds depth, and A7 creates a restless pull back — sophisticated heartbreak.
Three chords with a descending bass (A-G-F) — minimal but devastating. The Fmaj7 ending hangs in the air, unresolved.
i7-VImaj7-IIImaj7-iv7-VII7 — five seventh chords creating a bittersweet glow around the minor tonic, like remembering something beautiful that's gone.
I-vi-IV-V — the 'Heart and Soul' progression. The vi (Am) adds just enough tenderness to turn a happy progression intimate.
I-vi-IV — three chords that say everything. The Em adds vulnerability, the C adds warmth. No resolution needed.
I-vi-IV-V-I — the full romantic cycle with a satisfying return home. Like a love story with a happy ending.
IV-vi-I-V — starting on the subdominant (F) creates a gentle, yearning approach rather than a direct statement.
I-vi-IV-V in A — the F#m has a tender, introspective quality that pairs naturally with romantic lyrics.
I-iii-IV — three chords, no V. The iii chord (Em) is rarer and more intimate than vi. Ending on IV leaves things open and tender.
I-III7-vi-IV-V — the B7 (secondary dominant of Em) adds a passionate pull toward the vi chord, like a heart skipping a beat.
I-V-vi-IV — placing the minor chord after the dominant creates a swell-and-settle pattern, like waves of emotion.
vi-IV-V-I — starting minor and resolving to major mirrors the arc of falling in love: vulnerability leading to joy.
I-vi-IV-V-I — the complete cycle in E. The C#m has a particularly tender sound, and the return to E feels like an embrace.
Imaj7-vi7-ii7-V7 — the jazz standard turnaround. Seventh chords make every transition silky, like candlelight on everything.
IVmaj7-iii7-ii7 — three descending seventh chords. No resolution, just a slow, beautiful fall. Like a long exhale.
Imaj7-vi7-IVmaj7-ii7-V7 — five lush seventh chords. The longer cycle lets each chord breathe, like a slow dance.
Imaj7-vi7-ii7-V7 — the ii7-V7 resolution is the most romantic cadence in jazz. It sounds like coming home to someone.
Imaj7-vi7-IVmaj7-V7 — lush seventh chords throughout. The E7 resolves back to Amaj7 like a long, slow kiss.
